runs.text: Introduce
Read the title and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this story is realistic fiction. It has characters who behave like people students may know.
Have students point to the main character in the story.
Build Vocabulary
Introduce the word
supply
using the
Define/Example/Ask
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
Define:
Supply
is an amount of an item.
Example: I keep a
supply
of colored pencils in my desk.
Ask: Which items do we have a large
supply
of in the classroom?
Read
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
Check Comprehension
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question:
Find the name of the main character in the story. (Katy)
What does Katy love the most? Find the sentence that answers the question.
What happens to the familys supply of cheese each night?
Have you ever had a dream that seemed real? What happened in your dream?
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Introduce
Read the title and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that there are different kinds of sheep and different names for them. A baby sheep is called a lamb. A female sheep is called a ewe. A male sheep is called a ram.
Build Vocabulary
Introduce the word
goods
using the
Define/Example/Ask
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
Define:
Goods
are items that are made and sold.
Example: Food and clothes are
goods
people buy.
Ask: What
goods
can you buy at your local, or nearby, grocery store?
Read
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
Check Comprehension
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question:
Find the word that tells what animal Bo and Peep work with. (sheep)
What do sheep grow on their bodies? Find the sentence that answers the question.
How are some breeds of sheep alike? How are they different?
What goods can you buy that are made of wool? Why do people buy these goods?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read
Have students whisperread each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
Focus on Target Phonics Skill
Have students circle words with long
e
. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Write
Have students write a sentence using the word
leaves
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss Sentence Structure
Discuss the end punctuation mark for sentences 1 and 2.
Point out that both sentences are about eating cheese, but sentence 2 provides more information.
Have students identify which words are added to sentence 1 to build sentence 2 (before my meal).
Explain
Read the title. Explain that this is a poem with short lines, rhyming words, and descriptive language.
Read
For the first reading, have students echo-read the poem after you. Then pair students to reread the poem. Partners can switch stanzas during the rereadings.
Prompt
Prompt students to find all the words with long
e
spellings in the poem and circle them. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Offer Phonics Supports
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Offer High-Frequency Word Supports
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
These supports include the Read/Build/Write routine.
Read Aloud
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board and have students self-correct. Take note of each students errors on their Student Observation Form.
Introduce
Read the title and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that students will read about what cheese is made of.
Build Vocabulary
Introduce the word
ingredient
using the
Define/Example/Ask
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
Define:
An
ingredient
is something that is used to make food.
Example: We bought the
ingredient
for a cake at the food store.
Ask: Which
ingredients
do you need to make a pizza?
Read
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
Check Comprehension
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question:
Find the word that describes how cheese tastes. (yummy)
What is the main ingredient in cheese? Find the sentences that answer this question.
What do all of the animals in the oval have in common? Explain.
Which other foods are made from milk? Have you tried them?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read
Have students whisperread each sentence.
Then ask them to chorally read it.
Focus on Target Phonics Skill
Have students circle words with long
e
Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Write
Have students write a sentence using the word
monkey
Have them read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss Sentence Structure
Discuss the different end punctuation for sentences 1 (question mark), 2 (period), and 10 (exclamation point).
Model how you change your intonation when reading a question (raise voice at end) or exclamation (read with excitement). Have students echo-read the sentences, replicating your intonation.
Explain
Read the title and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this text includes steps in the process of making cheese.
Each step has a number and students must read the numbers in order.
Read
Guide students through a reading of the selection, including the steps.
Prompt
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when viewing the numbered steps.
Introduce

Read the title and have students repeat as they point to each word. This is an on-level selection. It is provided to gauge where students are in their reading progress toward grade-level goals. Students might need to listen and follow along with the eBook for support before they read the book on their own.
Explain to students that they will read a story about a monkey.
Build Vocabulary
Introduce the word
confront
using the
Define/Example/Ask
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
Define: Confront means to face someone or something.
Example: Maria will
confront
her little brother about her missing book.
Ask: Have you ever needed to
confront
, or face, your fears? What did you do?
Read
Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
Check Comprehension
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question:
Find when Monkey sleeps in a cozy cave with bear. (rainy nights)
Who confronts Monkey about the hat? Find the sentence that answers the question.
Does Monkey regret his decision to take the hat? Explain why or why not.
What would you do if a friend took something that belonged to you? How would you feel? What would you do to get it back?
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Introduce
Read the title and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this is a story about a flower and a bee that behave like humans. Ask students what problem they Bee and Daisy might have.
Build Vocabulary
Introduce the word
favor
using the
Define/Example/Ask
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
Define: A
favor
is a kind deed that someone does for someone else.
Example: I did my neighbor a
favor
by shoveling his sidewalk after the snowstorm.
Ask: When was the last time you did a
favor
for someone else? What did you do?
Read
Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback
Check Comprehension
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question:
Find the word that tells how Bee describes Daisy at first. (mean)
Why does Daisy feel sad? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Will Bee keep doing favors for Daisy? Why or why not?
Have you ever become friends with someone you did not get along with at first? Explain.
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
